House &Home/Style Desk; SECTD
Best Sellers and Bombs, And What Stores Hope Will Lure You Back
By RIMA SUQI
4117 words
28 January 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
1
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

IT should come as no surprise to anyone that 2009 wasn't a stellar year for retailers specializing in home furnishings -- or in just about anything else. According to the Census Bureau's most recent monthly retail trade report, sales at furniture and home furnishings stores were down 11.9 percent last year from 2008.

Even so, the news isn't all bad.

Despite the recession, some people are still buying, at least according to the owners of a number of design stores around the country who were asked to talk about what has sold well, what hasn't -- and what they're betting on -- in a time of economic turmoil.

The last time the Home section surveyed design stores about their sales and what they were hoping to score big with in the season ahead, the retail landscape looked very different. In the fall of 2007, there appeared to be little anxiety among store owners about the future, and most seemed willing to take chances on unconventional pieces, which often turned out to be unexpected best sellers.

The hand-painted ceramic pig carried by Auto in the meatpacking district was one such surprise, and it continued to sell well, to the amazement of the store's owners, Renata Bokalo and Roman Luba, until they closed their doors earlier this month. (They wouldn't comment on their reasons for closing.)

But of the 11 stores surveyed last time, Auto was the only one that went out of business. And several stores actually expanded: Apartment 48 in New York and Elements in Chicago moved to larger spaces, and Koo de Kir in Boston opened a second location devoted to interior design.

This time around, the retailers who were surveyed -- an entirely different group -- seemed more cautious. Larry Schaffer, the owner of OK in Los Angeles, said his strategy in the past year had been investing in ''greatest hits, things I knew would sell because I've sold them for 10 years.''

Ken Foster, the owner of Foster's Homeware, in Philadelphia, adopted a similar approach. ''I used to take risks and bring in a wacky thing that I knew wouldn't sell,'' Mr. Foster said. ''Now I spend my money on stuff I know will sell.''

And like most of the store owners interviewed for this article, he and Mr. Schaffer have kept their inventory lean: Mr. Foster cut his stock by 20 percent last year, Mr. Schaffer by 25 percent.

A few stores reported an uptick in sales -- of cocooning items, in particular. Pamela Hewett, the owner of Stitch, in Chicago, said she ''sold more sectionals in 2009 than any year prior'' in the past decade, a change she attributes to people ''hanging out more at home'' during the recession.

Homenature in Southampton, N.Y., also saw an increase in furniture sales, despite a sharp decrease in decorator traffic, said John Heilmann, the owner. ''I think our customer that used a decorator in the city might not have been using one for their second home out here,'' Mr. Heilmann said. ''They were doing it themselves.''

For a few stores, the recession seems to have provided an opportunity to test new waters. Because he reduced his inventory, Mr. Schaffer said, he had the cash to ''very strategically and carefully pick up new collections.''

''I'll probably have newer, fresher stuff this year than I've had in three years,'' he said.

What follows is a small, unscientific survey of the home furnishings market across the country -- one that is in no way exhaustive, since retailers can be expected to reserve some information for competitive reasons. But it does offer a look at what's still selling, even in the midst of an economic downturn.

For photos of the products mentioned throughout, view the interactive feature.

Grange Hall, 4445 Travis Street, Dallas; (214) 443-0600 or http://urbanflowergrangehall.com [http://urbanflowergrangehall.com]

Jeffrey Marion Lee and Rajan Patel, the owners, met when they worked for fashion designer Victor Costa. They went on to become visual directors at Stanley Korshak, a department store, before buying a 3,000-square-foot space six years ago in the Knox-Henderson area of Dallas. In the beginning, their shop focused on floral design, but over the years their product mix has expanded to include home furnishings, books and jewelry; they also offer interior design services. The store manager, Morgan Thaxton, describes the inventory as a ''highly curated selection of bizarre gifts and unusual jewelry from around the world.''

Best Seller: Mixed-Media Miniatures by David Simcik, $225 to $375 Each ''We tend to gravitate toward finding the beauty in the grotesque, and so does our clientele,'' Ms. Thaxton said. ''We have a lot of art collectors who respond to Simcik's work. He embodies our store by combining past and present and sweet and gritty and precious and mechanical. They're all one of a kind and affordable.''

Bomb: Seduction Porcelain Vase by Sieger by Furstenberg; White, $410; Platinum, $1,080 ''We do have that customer that gets titillated by all sorts of things, and we thought they'd love this vase. They saw the humor, but that didn't clinch the sale. Maybe it's the price -- but the platinum isn't a silver glaze, it is actual platinum! We joke that while the saying goes, 'Everything's bigger in Texas,' these just weren't ample enough for the Dallas set.''

Betting On: Gilded Porcelain Elephant Knife Rests by Sieger by Furstenberg, $220 Each ''We try to keep an edited selection of little treasures in our store. This is a small object, but it elevates the table to a luxury level. They're pricey, but they're made of porcelain and hand-gilded with 24-karat gold. We love the bit of comedy in them -- that little dining companion on your table.''

Gretel, (786) 247-9003 or gretelhome.com

Abby Kellett, Gretel's owner, is an interiors stylist who got her start in 2004, at Elle Decoration magazine in London. Later that year, she moved to Miami and became the style director for Inside Out magazine, now defunct, leaving in 2007 to have a baby and to do freelance styling for commercial and residential interiors. She started Gretel last year as a Web-only venture, but during Art Basel Miami Beach in December, she set up a pop-up shop in the city's design district and plans to do the same thing next year. ''With an online store, you don't get much contact with people,'' Ms. Kellett said. ''So it was nice to sit there, with all my product around me, and actually talk to people.''

Best Seller: Talking Heads Beechwood Coat Hangers, $149 for Six ''They look like art when installed on a wall, whether mounted in a straight line or haphazardly,'' Ms. Kellett said. ''There's something tactile about them as well. They're a nice size, beautifully made, easy to install and serve a purpose without costing a fortune.''

Bomb: Omaggio Vases by Ditte Reckweg and Jelena Schou Nordentoft for Kahler, $39 to $98 ''These embody what we're about -- modern but really beautifully decorative and with a handmade touch to them. They have a real New England feel about them to me, but maybe for Miami they're a little too understated. I still have hope for them; maybe in the summer season, they'll appeal to people a bit more.''

Betting On: Frame Lights by Iacoli &McAllister, $145 to $225 ''I had three of these hanging in my pop-up store during Design Miami, and people really liked them. There's something minimal about them, but they have the right touch of decoration to them, and they come in vibrant candy colors like green, yellow and magenta.''

Stitch, 1723 North Damen Avenue, Chicago; (773) 782-1570 or stitchchicago.com

Pamela Hewett already owned a successful fashion-accessories store in the Lakeview area of Chicago in 1998, when a space opened up in the Wicker Park neighborhood where she lived. ''I wanted to do something bigger, and I wanted to sell furniture,'' she said -- and this was before Wicker Park and the neighboring Bucktown area became the retail mecca they are now. Today, she describes Stitch as a lifestyle store with a 50-50 split between home furnishings and fashion accessories.

Best Seller: Animal Shot Glasses by Goody Grams, $34 Each

''These put a smile on people's faces -- do a shot, forget your problems,'' Ms. Hewett said. ''We sold a lot of Moose and Deer; maybe that's because we're in the Midwest. I also think that with the whole Americana trend -- guys with Grizzly Adams beards and plaid shirts -- these fit in well.''

Bomb: Delano White Leather Chair by GUS*, $865

''I thought this chair was so good looking; it looked like it belonged on the 'Mad Men' set. But it is just too hard-edged for our customers in Chicago. Here, it is all about comfort, nesting and curling up. It comes in black leather too, and neither one sold well.''

Betting On: Cu Cu Clock by Umberto Tolino for Progetti, $385

''This is an organic but modern piece of art that makes you laugh. That little bird comes out of this perfectly crafted Italian piece of art; it makes several different traditional bird sounds and is perfectly chirpy. They successfully mixed an Italian aesthetic with a kooky German idea.

Homenature, 6 Main Street, Southampton, N.Y.; (631) 287-6277 or homenature.com

John Heilmann opened the first Homenature store in Amagansett 13 years ago, with just $2,000. In 2004, he opened a second location, in Southampton. But the two stores competed with each other, so he consolidated all operations in Southampton the following year. ''Southampton has a busier downtown, and is a less seasonal town,'' Mr. Heilmann said. He describes his current environment as ''a naturally elegant mix of vintage and production pieces, with a few surprises.''

Best Seller: Peace Sign Doormat, $25

''It's a fun item and an appropriate message for the entrance of a home,'' Mr. Heilmann said. ''The black-and-white color combination is classic; it didn't limit anyone from buying it. If it were green or orange, someone might hesitate.''

Bomb: Vintage 1970s Glasses, $20 each

''We sold other vintage glasses really well, but they weren't pornographic in nature. Once you put cold water in these, the women 'lose' their clothes. I thought these would be a hysterical gift for a guy, and a lot of people picked them up, but nobody bought them. I think it's the price -- at $20 each, you're spending $160 for eight, and that's a more serious price than some might want to pay for a fun thing.''

Betting On: Driftwood Candelabra, $215

''People are always looking for something to put in the middle of the dining room table. This speaks to that and is functional. An organic shape like this, against a really clean surface, looks more dramatic and like sculpture. These are pretty and they aren't small -- about 30 inches long by 12 inches wide. I think they'll have a wide appeal.''

HW Home 1941 Pearl Street, Boulder, Colo.; (303) 545-0320 or hwhome.com

Since the first HW Home store opened in Boulder 10 years ago, the company has made it its mission to provide ''Mountain Modern'' style to a clientele ranging from urban professionals to mountain residents with second homes in the city (in this case, Denver). The owners, Ron Werner and Jim Hering, hail from Chicago, where Mr. Werner was a senior vice president at Smith Barney and Mr. Hering a general manager at Holly Hunt. When Mr. Werner's sister asked them to help decorate her Boulder home, they not only fell in love with the area, but realized it was lacking what they refer to as an ''entry-level, high-end'' home furnishings boutique. They now have three more Colorado stores -- in Denver, Broomfield and Greenwood Village.

Best Seller: Czech Glass Martini Glasses and Wine Goblets, $60 Each

''We're the only ones in Colorado that carry this line of glassware,'' Mr. Werner said. ''The glasses are pretty substantial -- you can use the martini glass or as a dessert dish -- and when you pick them up, you feel that they're heavy.''

Bomb: Earthenware Tableware by Bizzirri, $17.50 to $75 Each

''Sometimes you take a chance on pieces because you love them. We designed this collection with a studio in Italy, and we chose a dramatic look and color combination that attracts a very specific customer. I think it might be a little much for every day.''

Betting On: K9 Dog Beds by Mitchell Gold + Bob Williams, $200 to $1,050

''We're going to stock them in a machine washable fabric that's contract-grade, so it's durable and easy to take care of.''

The Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street, New York; (866) 755-9079 or conranusa.com

The first Conran shop, specializing in modern furniture and home accessories, opened in 1973 on Fulham Road in London. It wasn't until 1999 that the retailer opened a New York store, but the timing -- at the height of the modernist craze -- was perfect. After 10 years in the same location, under the Queensboro Bridge, the Conran Shop will move to an 8,500-square-foot space at ABC Carpet &Home in April. While the address will change, we're told the product mix will remain the same.

Best Seller: Melamine Nesting Bowl Set by Joseph Joseph, $59

''I think the three main draws were color, function and space-saving -- it's fun and affordable,'' said David Branham, the buyer for the New York Conran Shop, explaining why the set was such a hit. ''We did a lot of gifting with this item, especially for people in their first apartments.''

Bomb: Boat Seat With Umbrella by Ben Fowler, $8,450

''This is a 100 percent functional boat -- it floats. It comes with a bracket you put on the floor, which holds it steady while you lounge on it. It was handmade by Ben Fowler as part of a project where we gave some artists and designers free rein to create something -- based on Terence's book 'Inspiration' -- and we'd put it in the shop. We put it on the floor on Sept. 19, 2008, which was right about the time the bottom started to fall out of the economy.''

Betting On: Louisiane Powder-Coated Galvanized Steel Bench, $695

''New Yorkers are loving all the classic outdoor cafe furniture, thanks to the city installing so much of it in the new medians, like at Ninth Avenue and 14th Street, beside the Apple store,'' said Mr. Branham. This bench is from a French manufacturer whose goods we've sold for years. It stands out because of color and style -- it's got great curves.''

Foster's Homeware, 33 North Third Street, Philadelphia; (800) 734-8511 or shopfosters.com

Foster's opened in 1995, in the Old City area of Philadelphia, as a high-end cookware store. It was the vision of Ken Foster, who had been an art major at Rutgers but had worked in retail management for 15 years. ''There weren't any independent stores in downtown Philly in the '90s,'' Mr. Foster said, ''and I found my niche.'' As the area grew, so did the store, which now sells high-design items for every room of the home.

Best Seller: Curve Ceramic Teapot by ForLife, $34

''It's an old-fashioned teapot with a big belly shape, but a modern contemporary design,'' Mr. Foster said. ''We carry it in eight different colors, and they look great on the shelf. And it's a great price.''

Bomb: Club Fondue Set by Sagaform, $55

''We've sold fondue pots every Christmas since we opened; this is the first time we didn't sell any. This Christmas, people were buying practical gifts, and while it's a luxury thing you might splurge on, nobody needs a fondue pot. The people who are into it already have theirs -- as a trend, fondue is finally over.''

Betting On: Die-Cut Felt Trivets by Verso Design, $17 to $44

''These are made by a mother-daughter team in Finland. They base their designs on Finnish shapes -- the ones I ordered look like a berry plant. They're thick, the colors are perfect, they're functional but decorative and I haven't seen them before.''

The Paris Market, 36 West Broughton Street, Savannah, Ga.; (912) 232-1500 or theparismarket.com

Paula Danyluk spent 11 years working as a speech pathologist, but she harbored a passion for interior design, helping friends decorate their homes and scouring blogs to keep up to date on the latest trends. In 2004, she and her husband, Taras Danyluk, an emergency-room physician, opened a home-accessories shop they initially called the Paris Flea Market. Within a year, they had outgrown their 1,100-square-foot space and moved to a spot five times bigger on what is now a bustling thoroughfare. Ms. Danyluk describes their store as ''French style meets industrial'' -- or ''an industrial table with a drippy chandelier over it and a velvet chair in the corner.''

Best Seller: Throw Pillows by Ryan Studios, $120 to $150

''We have very traditional Southern homes in this town,'' Ms. Danyluk said. ''And these elegant, velvet pillows fit in very well with a Southern interior. They're down-filled and very well made, and nobody else in town carries such a nice brand.''

Bomb: Romero Chair by Cisco Brothers, $4,032

''The company that makes this chair is family-owned and makes everything in the U.S. -- the quality is amazing. But it doesn't seem people care about quality anymore; I feel there's a rooms-to-go mentality out there. If someone can get a chair like this for $1,000, they want it. But for $4,000, they want an antique.''

Betting On: Fold-In Chandelier by Tim Adams, $1,800

''The scale of this piece is very dramatic -- it's 54 inches wide by 45 inches high -- and it's handmade by a local artist who is pretty hot right now. I think it's a great price for a handmade item, and he'll custom-make this in different sizes and with different patinas.''

Propeller, 555 Hayes Street, San Francisco; (415) 701-7767 or propellermodern.com

Lorn Dittfeld, the owner, grew up in Miami and spent summers working at an uncle's custom furniture shop. Yet he majored in finance, worked in advertising and traveled the world for a year before finally settling in San Francisco, where he took classes in architecture and color theory at the University of California, Berkeley. ''I knew I was on the design highway, but didn't know which exit I should get off at,'' Mr. Dittfeld said. At a friend's suggestion, he opened Propeller in 2002, with the aim of making furniture, doing interior design and selling the work of independent and emerging designers

Best Seller: Light Bulb by SMC, $48 to $138

''People like the shape and seem intrigued by the intricacy of it. They associate this bulb with something that is old -- it is a feeling of nostalgia, and nostalgia is a happy place. All that aside, they're beautiful objects, they shine and reflect other light. It's almost a completely unpretentious piece of art,'' said Mr. Dittfeld.

Bomb: War Bowl, Made of Melted Toy Soldiers, by Dominic Wilcox, $400

''In this moment we're in, maybe they're too frivolous. It's a $400 bowl that you certainly won't be putting any soup in. You can't even use it as a fruit bowl. It's an object, in of itself, and it can't be anything more than that.''

Betting On: Cain Collection Chair by Seth Eshelman for Staach, $300 to $425 Each

''I think these guys are doing great stuff,'' Mr. Dittfeld said. ''The chair itself is a clean, simple design -- the antidote to the opulence and extravagance of the zeros decade. They harken back to an earlier era of small shops, almost a Shaker type of idea. And I think it's a good price.''

OK, 8303 West Third Street, Los Angeles; (323) 653-3501 or okthestore.com

When Larry Schaffer opened OK in 2002, it quickly became a destination for design aficionados from all over the country. Mr. Schaffer is a veteran of the furniture business: in the late '80s, as a 25-year-old, he was put in charge of a furniture store in Los Angeles that he declines to name, but describes as being ''like Modern Age was in New York at that time.'' After it ''crashed and burned,'' he said, he did odd jobs, like working at a glass gallery, before starting his own home-accessories business with just $5,000, two years before he opened OK. He describes his clientele as ''extremely smart, sophisticated and hip, but not in my field. They know as much about fashion, literature and film as I know about design.''

Best Seller: Leather bookends by Sandy Voor, $150 to $185 a pair (sold out)

''I travel all over the world and so does my customer. Things have become so global that you'll see some of the same things in each store, whether it's 10 Corso Como or Colette,'' Mr. Schaffer said, referring to the well-known stores in Milan and Paris. ''But you won't see these everywhere, because they're handmade by a woman in upstate New York. People like something that was made by a real person. I put these in our children's book section, and I had to reorder them four times in December.''

Bomb: Blown-glass bowl by Bill Burch, $325

''Because I used to work for a vintage glass dealer, I know that Bill's stuff is extremely sophisticated and well made. If my customers were glass aficionados, they'd realize this and want it. But they're not, which is why we stopped selling really expensive glass a few years ago.''

Betting On: Ceramic tube vases by Josh Herman, $200 to $300

''People are really interested in pottery right now. It's earthy and understated. The thing that is hardest to find are ceramics that are simple and pure, but also beautiful. These are beautifully thrown, but what makes them is the glaze -- Josh does very skilled work.''

Kuhl-Linscomb, 2424 West Alabama, Houston; (713) 526-6000 or kuhl-linscomb.com

Most stores featured here are small boutiques, but Kuhl-Linscomb is an exception -- a 70,000-square-foot store spanning five buildings, owned by the husband-and-wife team Pam Kuhl-Linscomb and Dan Linscomb. Mrs. Kuhl-Linscomb started an interior design firm in 1984, and the couple opened the store 10 years later. Their product mix includes nearly everything for the home -- both new and antique -- along with stationery, CD's, jewelry and apothecary items. The company offers interior design services as well, focusing on specific spaces like closets and kitchens.

Best Seller: Screw Dining Tables by Tom Dixon, $1,700 or $1,260

''The table has an industrial look and Old World look at the same time -- the marble top has a great patina to it -- so it appealed to a wide range of customers,'' Ms. Kuhl-Linscomb said. ''And Tom Dixon is really hot right now, so people who know him love that table even more.''

Bomb: Third Drawer Down Linen Tea Towels, $42 Each

''These are beautifully designed, but not easy to understand. We think we had them in the wrong area -- we tried to merchandise them with our traditional tea towels, and I think they cater to a more artistic customer.''

Betting On:

La Stanza Dello Scirocco Baskets by Mario Trimarchi for Alessi, $32 to $120 Each ''We noticed a lot of geometric shapes in design right now. We're displaying this in a setting at the center of a table, and people notice it right away -- it's gotten a lot of interest. It's in an area with other designers that this customer likes or will recognize, like Philippe Starck and Michael Graves.''

PHOTOS (PHOTOGRAPHS ABOVE, PETER DASILVA FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES; TOP RIGHT, TONY CENICOLA/THE NEW YORK TIMES)(D1); PHOTOS (D6); PHOTOS; (PHOTOGRAPHS BY CLAUDIA URIBE TOUR); (PHOTOGRAPHS BY TONY CENICOLA/THE NEW YORK TIMES) (D7)

The New York Times Company

Business/Financial Desk; SECTB
Sales of New Homes Fell 7.6% in December
By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
508 words
28 January 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
11
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

WASHINGTON -- Sales of new homes unexpectedly fell 7.6 percent last month, capping the industry's weakest year on record.

December's sales fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 342,000 from an upwardly revised November pace of 370,000, the Commerce Department said Wednesday. Economists surveyed by Thomson Reuters had forecast a pace of 370,000 for December.

The results were the weakest since March and indicated demand remained sluggish despite newly expanded tax incentives to spur sales. The report will probably fuel concern that the housing market turnaround will falter when government support ends this spring.

Tom Brown, co-owner of Crown Home Builders in Summerville, S.C., was not surprised that last month was poor. Buyers are having trouble meeting tough criteria for mortgage loans, he said. And though builders are cutting prices, the shaky economy and weak job market are keeping home shoppers away.

''People are holding on to what they have,'' he said.

Only 374,000 homes were sold last year, down 23 percent from a year earlier and the weakest year on record dating back to 1963. December's sales were nearly 9 percent below the same month last year. This year, the National Association of Homebuilders is forecasting more than 500,000 sales.

Even if that happens, ''it hardly makes you ecstatic,'' said Bernard M. Markstein, senior economist at the trade group, noting that the industry clocked more than 1 million sales a year from 2003 through 2006

Home sales have had a rocky recovery from their four-year slide. December's sales pace for new homes was up 4 percent from the bottom in January 2009, but down 75 percent from the peak in July 2005.

The median sales price of $221,300 in December was down nearly 4 percent from $229,600 a year earlier, but up about 5 percent from November's median of $210,300.

New-home sales varied widely across the country. Sales of new homes plummeted by 41 percent in the Midwest and fell by 7 percent in the South. But they skyrocketed 43 percent in the Northeast and rose 5 percent in the West.

Any housing recovery this year will probably be slow. Experts forecast sales of new and previously occupied homes to weaken after tax credits for homebuyers expire in April.

So far, the housing recovery has been fueled mainly by hundreds of billions in federal spending that has pushed down mortgage rates and propped up demand. Congress decided last year to extend a tax credit of up to $8,000 for first-time buyers until the end of April. Homeowners who have lived in their current properties for at least five years can claim a tax credit of up to $6,500 if they relocate.

CHARTS: New-Home Sales: Annual pace of new private homes sold during the month, seasonally adjusted.; Prices of New Homes: Median price for new homes.(Source: Commerce Department)

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100128e61s0001o


Business/Financial Desk; SECTB
Housing Indexes for November Indicate a Pause, but Not a Plunge
By DAVID STREITFELD
811 words
27 January 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
3
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

The recovery in the housing market is still alive, barely.

Home prices managed a 0.2 percent seasonally adjusted gain in November from the previous month, according to the Standard &Poor's Case-Shiller Home Price Index.

The data, released Tuesday, reflected frenzied activity in 20 major cities as people competed to buy houses to take advantage of a government tax credit. But all those sales did not produce much more than flat prices.

A second index released on Tuesday showed a healthier market. The Federal Housing Finance Agency said its price index, which uses data from mortgages that have been sold to or guaranteed by the government, rose 0.7 percent in November from the previous month. But the agency also revised its October figures downward.

To blur the picture even more, a third national housing price index was released last week. Issued by the data firm First American CoreLogic, it showed a decline of 0.2 percent in November.

Put all these indexes together, and a portrait emerges of a market going nowhere.

''The winter pause that people thought was going to happen seems to be happening,'' said Maureen Maitland, vice president for index services at S.&P.

A pause is certainly better than a plunge, which is what was happening during 2007 and 2008. But sales have slowed markedly since November. It is only a matter of time, the analysts say, before prices also undergo at least a slight dip.

''We expect home price deflation to resume in the December or January Case-Shiller indices and continue through 2010,'' Zelman &Associates wrote in a research note.

The 20-city Case-Shiller composite price index is down 29.2 percent from its peak in the second quarter of 2006 and 5.3 percent over the last year. Average home prices are where they were in late 2003.

Prices in five of the cities fell in November from the previous month, while 15 rose. Las Vegas managed to snap its long losing streak and eke out a 0.1 percent gain. The strongest cities were on the West Coast, including San Francisco, San Diego and Los Angeles. The five that fell included Chicago, Miami and New York.

The West Coast Case-Shiller numbers were backed up by the Federal Housing Finance Agency data, which showed that the Pacific was the strongest of nine United States regions both for the month and the last year.

Nothing is simple about real estate these days, however. Jim Klinge, an agent in northern San Diego who keeps a close watch on sales trends, recently published on his blog comparative statistics for the first 15 days of January going back 12 years.

There were 61 closed deals in the two weeks this year, which places 2010 roughly between the 1999 peak of 125 and the 2008 nadir of 36. But the price buyers are paying per square foot -- one of the most accurate measures of pricing trends -- is still falling. Last year it was $410 a foot; this year, it is $368.

The local market ''is blazingly hot,'' Mr. Klinge said, but only for sellers who want to get rid of their place, quickly.

''These sellers feel like they're giving the house away, which is what buyers want,'' he said. ''If the sellers price the house too high, no one will even look at it.''

The only sellers who can do this, of course, are ones willing and able to take a big loss. Mr. Klinge showed a house Tuesday that was for sale for $800,000. The owners had paid $975,000 a few years ago, so they will lose nearly all their down payment. ''It was a second home, and they just wanted to be rid of it,'' the agent said.

Seasonal adjustments are affecting the numbers in San Diego and everywhere else. These have the effect of smoothing out swings in the raw numbers. On an unadjusted basis, the individual cities in the Case-Shiller index fared worse: 13 fell, while the composite price index dropped 0.2 percent.

The Conference Board's monthly measure of consumer confidence, also released Tuesday, rose to 55.9 in January from a revised 53.6 in December. That was more of an improvement than analysts had expected but still low by historical standards.

Dan Greenhaus, chief economic strategist with Miller Tabak, said that the long-term average was about 95, and that the high reading was 144 early in 2000. ''Clearly more work on the confidence front needs to be done,'' he said.

PHOTO: A home in San Francisco, which has had some gains in home prices, according to the Standard &Poor's Case-Shiller index. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JUSTIN SULLIVAN/GETTY IMAGES)

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100127e61r0000d


PROPERTY VALUES
Real Estate Desk; SECT
What You Get for ... $250,000
By MIKE POWELL
719 words
27 January 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
The New York Times on the Web
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

ASHEVILLE, N.C.

WHAT: A one-bedroom one-bath condo

HOW MUCH: $249,900 (or $274,900 for the condo and one unit of street-level commercial space, although both can be sold separately)

SIZE: 761 square feet

PER SQUARE FOOT: $328.38

SETTING: This condo is one of nine apartments in an 1885 building in downtown Asheville. (Before condo conversion in 2002, the building was an art gallery, and before that, a department store.) Asheville, between the Blue Ridge and the Great Smoky Mountains in western North Carolina, has a strong reputation for good food, art, music and architecture. Tourism, second-home ownership and retirement communities thrive in the area. Public schools are within a mile and a half.

INSIDE: The apartment's current owner -- also the building's developer -- repurposed materials from the building's conversion. The kitchen and bathroom cabinets are made from the department store's old shelving. Pine paneling from the store's office walls was converted to flooring. Tin ceilings were reused as shower surrounds and fireplace panels.

Windows in the living room are nearly floor-to-ceiling and have mountain views. The bedroom has an adjoining office area with a built-in desk, and a walk-in closet.

OUTDOOR SPACE: None, though the house is within a 20-minute drive of the Pisgah National Forest, the Nantahala National Forest and Great Smoky Mountains National Park, which has over 800 miles of trails.

TAXES: $2,026 a year; $201.04 a month in condo association dues.

CONTACT: Gail Lamb, for sale by owner, (828) 275-4500; fsbo-northcarolina.com

MILTON, N.H.

WHAT: A four-bedroom two-and-a-half bath cape

HOW MUCH: $249,900

SIZE: 2,256 square feet

PER SQUARE FOOT: $110.77

SETTING: This house is on 29 acres off a state route through Milton, a town of about 4,500 on the Maine border. Most residents drive to Rochester or neighboring Farmington for groceries and other shopping. Milton is about 20 miles from a handful of skiing areas, and 30 miles from beaches along the Atlantic Ocean. There are three ponds nearby, too.

INSIDE: This house was built in 1790 and added on to periodically since then. Many interior details -- including wide-plank wood floors, exposed ceiling beams and built-in storage throughout -- are original.

In the living room is the original center chimney, with a brick fireplace and a slate hearth. French doors open to a dining room with a slanted, sky-lit ceiling and a wood-burning fireplace. The eat-in kitchen has cathedral ceilings. One of the first-floor bedrooms has a fireplace and built-in storage for books and clothes.

There are two fireplaces in the master suite -- one in the bedroom and one in the bathroom; in addition, there is a sitting room. Upstairs are the house's two other bedrooms, both with built-in storage spaces.

A bunkhouse adjacent to the garage -- originally a storage barn -- has a bedroom, a bathroom, a living room (with a wood-burning stove), an eat-in kitchen and storage areas.

OUTDOOR SPACE: There is a half-acre blueberry grove to the left of the driveway, raised beds and perennial plantings, apple trees, and some trails that run through this mostly wooded property.

TAXES: $5,418 a year.

CONTACT: Cheryl Schlenker, Costantino Real Estate, LLC, (603) 539-3200 x 205; ossipeelakere.com

SAN DIEGO

WHAT: A one-bedroom one-bath condo

HOW MUCH: $250,000

SIZE: 732 square feet

PER SQUARE FOOT: $341.53

SETTING: This apartment is in a 42-unit building in Mission Hills, a mostly residential area known for its midcentury architecture. Nearby is the neighborhood of Hillcrest, where there are several shops and restaurants. Mission Hills Park (and tennis courts) is a block west.

INSIDE: The living room has a freestanding wood fireplace. The master bedroom has a walk-in closet. The kitchen was recently remodeled. The condo comes with two parking spots in the building's gated underground garage.

OUTDOOR SPACE: A shared courtyard in the center of the building, and a pool.

TAXES: $3,125 a year; $285 a month in homeowner's association fees

CONTACT: Pepper Coffey, Prudential California Realty, (619) 446-6956; prudentialcaliforniarealtyonline.com
