LIVING IN PEARL RIVER, N.Y.
Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
Lots for the Family to Love
By ELSA BRENNER
1630 words
17 January 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
7
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

A ROCKLAND County hamlet in Orangetown, several miles southwest of Nyack, Pearl River is not nearly as trendy as its neighbors. It doesn't have Hudson River views or storied estates. Its downtown of unadorned storefronts is a plain Jane next to Nyack's or Piermont's.

But residents like Cathy and Peter Clancy have found more than enough to satisfy them. One asset they cite is simple good looks: small- and medium-size Capes and colonials on well-kept lots. Another is the homespun values of many residents and merchants.

It has been 14 years since they paid in the low $200,000s for a four-bedroom two-bath ranch on a quarter acre. Today the Clancys -- he is a police sergeant in New York City and she is a saleswoman for a trade show company -- are rearing three children in Pearl River. It's a place without pretensions, Mrs. Clancy said -- ''a good place for a family.''

Another plus: Even as home prices in trendier neighboring towns rose sharply in the early 2000s and then plummeted in the market crash, the value of the Clancys' ranch inched slowly up to the $400,000s and held relatively steady.

As Richard Ellis, the managing member of Ellis Sotheby's International Realty in Nyack, put it, ''Properties next to the Hudson had more demand and soared in price more quickly. And while communities like Pearl River did not, they also did not fall as much in value. It's been a safe, solid investment for a lot of buyers.''

Not that the poor economy hasn't been felt in the hamlet. The four-block downtown shopping area, especially, is pockmarked with vacancies.

''These days we live in the shadow of malls,'' said Jack Neugarten, known as Ed, and the owner since 1978 of Ed's Market, an old-style butcher shop with sawdust on the floors. Mr. Neugarten prides himself on knowing most customers by name, and on the quality of his meat -- in particular the corned beef. It is especially sought after around St. Patrick's Day, as census numbers show about 47 percent of residents are of Irish descent, and the second-largest St. Patrick's Day parade in the state is held there (the largest being in Manhattan), according to Denis M. Troy, a former president of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, an Irish Catholic group with some 700 members in the area.

Bemoaning the proximity of the Palisades Center in West Nyack, the Nanuet Mall in Nanuet, and large stores just to the south in New Jersey, which do not tax clothing, Mr. Neugarten declared, ''They do an injustice to small merchants like myself.''

Still, said Mr. Troy, an Orangetown councilman who lives in Pearl River, getting any kind of competitive traction in the current economy isn't easy for a hamlet without its own government.

As one of 10 hamlets and 4 villages in Orangetown (among them Piermont and part of Nyack), Pearl River must vie for government grants to improve sidewalks and lighting and otherwise make the downtown a more desirable shopping destination.

And as for becoming a village -- with its own local government and presumably more clout -- that idea is not popular with most residents, said Daniel G. Smith, a landscaper and member of the local Rotary Club who grew up in Pearl River. ''If the town had its own administration,'' he said, ''it would just present another level of taxes, and most of us don't want that.''

WHAT YOU'LL FIND

Pearl River has about 16,000 people; it is 17 miles north of Manhattan and just north of New Jersey. Slightly less than half of its seven-square-mile area is zoned residential. Of the rest, about half a square mile is set aside as open space and about a third of a square mile as parkland; the remainder is commercial, according to the assessor's office.

One of the largest parks is the municipal Blue Hill Golf Course to the east, overlooking Lake Tappan, a reservoir that cuts through Orangetown.

The hamlet was laid out in the 1870s around Central Avenue downtown. Today, roads fanning out from the avenue are lined with tidy bungalows, ranches, Capes and colonials, on lots of one-eighth to three-fourths of an acre throughout the hilly terrain.

One large commercial landholder is Glorious Sun Robert Martin, a Manhattan- and Hong Kong-based real estate company that owns the 1.1 million square foot Blue Hill Plaza, one of the largest office parks between New York City and Albany. The two Blue Hill buildings -- the taller one, at 21 stories, was one of the county's first skyscrapers in the early 1970s -- are on 93 heavily treed acres along Veteran's Memorial Drive in the southeast section. Pfizer, another major commercial landowner, occupies a 550-acre site, most of it in the northern part of the hamlet.

WHAT YOU'LL PAY

Prices range from $329,000, for a two-bedroom one-and-a-half-bath ranch, to $1.135 million for a five-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath colonial. The median for a single-family house in 2009 was $418,000, down from $445,000 the year before and $443,300 in 2004, according to the Lower Hudson Valley Multiple Listing Service.

Mr. Smith, 52, the Rotarian, says it was in 1951 that his father, Lawrence, now 89, bought the colonial that the two men now share with a third-generation family member, his son Sean, 22. The eldest Mr. Smith paid $13,000.

Newcomers like Dan and Kate Inserra, who own Danny's BBQ Bar &Grill in the downtown, are dealing with a vastly different market. But Pearl River still offers bargains, especially compared with many other sections of Rockland. For instance the listing service put the median for a single-family in Upper Nyack last year at $550,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Inserra, who are renting a carriage house for $1,000 a month, are looking to spend about $400,000 on a three- or four-bedroom house. ''We have lots to choose from,'' Mr. Inserra said, explaining that they will wait to see if prices drop further, but will act in time to take advantage of the government's tax credit for first-time home buyers. Realtor.com now lists eight single-families from $400,000 to $450,000, including a four-bedroom two-bath ranch at $428,998, with taxes of $7,773 a year. Condominiums start at $165,000, for a studio; a two-bedroom one-and-a-half-bath is listed at $284,500. In total, there are about a dozen now listed.

WHAT TO DO

A focus of the downtown entertainment scene is Jane on Main, a combination restaurant/gathering place/shop that its owner, Jane Carroll, opened in August. It has become a favorite destination for many groups, among them young mothers with toddlers during the day, and couples and young singles later on. Kenneth Olori, 23, a lifelong resident, who repairs construction equipment, often heads to one of the several bars in towns with friends, or to Pearl River Lanes for a night of bowling. Increasingly, though, he spends evenings at Jane on Main, which, as he put it, offers ''good food and good conversation.''

For families like the Clancys, with school-age children, the general area offers a variety of recreational pursuits. During Christmas vacation, Mrs. Clancy and her three children -- a girl, 12, and boys 10 and 7 -- skied at Mount Peter in nearby Warwick and skated on an outdoor ice rink at Bear Mountain.

THE SCHOOLS

The Pearl River School District, which encompasses most of the hamlet of Pearl River as well as slivers of Orangeburg, West Nyack, Nanuet and Tappan, has an enrollment of about 2,700 in three elementary schools, a middle school and a high school.

Of fourth-graders last year, 92 percent met state proficiency standards in English and 97 percent in math, versus 77 and 87 percent statewide.

SAT averages last spring were 531 in reading, 563 in math and 535 in writing, versus 480, 500 and 470 statewide.

Of the 198 graduates in 2009, said Sandy Cokely, a district spokeswoman, 70 percent are attending four-year colleges, 23 percent are at two-year colleges and 1 percent at vocational schools. Another 2 percent entered the military, 1 percent joined the work force and the rest were undecided.

THE COMMUTE

The train commute to the city on New Jersey Transit's Pascack Valley Line to Secaucus Junction and then Pennsylvania Station, or to Hoboken and then via PATH train, takes about 55 minutes. A monthly ticket costs $215. Some commuters drive about 25 minutes to the park-and-ride section of the Vince Lombardi Service Area of the New Jersey Turnpike and board a New Jersey Transit bus into the Port Authority, which takes another 30 minutes or so, depending on traffic.

THE HISTORY

Pearl River, originally called Muddy Brook, was renamed about 1870, after a resident said he had discovered pearls in mussels from the waterway, according to Robert P. Knight, an author of a book published in honor of the hamlet's centennial in 1973. Julius E. Braunsdorf bought and developed the land in the early 1870s, donating a strip of property running through it to the now-defunct New Jersey and New York Railroad.

PHOTO: STRIKING: Bowling is a popular pastime in Pearl River, a Rockland hamlet that makes up for its lack of Hudson River views with tidy streets and affordable real estate. (PHOTOGRAPH BY SUSAN STAVA FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

MAP

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100117e61h00032


Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
SOLD TOO SOON?
By HARVEY ARATON
2235 words
17 January 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
1
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

MY face betrayed me, disbelief slowly turning to distress as I stared silently at the Sunday real estate listings spread out on the kitchen table. It was a look my wife had seen too many times.

''Brooklyn?'' she said.

I nodded, obediently and guiltily.

''Why do that to yourself?''

I shook my head and pretended I hadn't heard the question.

''I can't believe what these apartments are going for.''

I couldn't blame my wife, Beth Albert, for wanting to scream, ''Enough already!'' She has had to live with my real estate remorse for years, but I just couldn't stop myself from rubbernecking when passing by the wreckage of our long-ago investment.

It has been 16 1/2 years since we sold a two-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn Heights, en route to the suburbs and the birth of a second child. Actually, I should say that we gave it away: We lost about $80,000 on a $240,000 purchase made in 1988.

We were far from alone in our selling frenzy during the housing downturn of the early 1990s. In our four-unit brick town house, everyone wanted out of a bad marriage to the dowdy adjoining building with 10 smaller apartments, officially part of our co-op. We were all fed up with internecine issues that created financial stress and tension among neighbors and friends.

With credit tight and our co-op financials barking like rabid dogs, Beth and I were ecstatic when our banker told us he would allow a qualified buyer to assume our mortgage. Fantasizing, we put our place on the market for what we had paid for it, $240,000. Weeks later, a nice young doctor and his wife came along to pick up the roughly $140,000 we owed and to cover our closing and moving expenses.

In return, they received 1,000-plus square feet in a third-floor walk-up that featured a loftlike living room with a custom-built full wall unit (our addition), a modern bath and kitchen, and a closet containing a stacked washer-dryer. With a health club and a train station around the corner, it was bright, convenient living, gloriously enhanced by rear-building parking.

We moved away in early summer 1993, and I had no reason to look back, not until 2 1/2 years later when the doctor's wife called. She needed me -- the co-op board president at the time of our departure -- to sign over a document to my successor to execute the sale of her apartment.

When I asked how she had made out, she said, ''You really want to know?'' Her pitying tone told me everything. The market had taken off and she and the good doctor had made a quick killing. I soon had a new hobby, punishing myself with an occasional browsing of the Brooklyn listings, the fine print shouting, ''What were you thinking?'' I've indulged in this torture ever since.

I will admit that dwelling on the past is nonproductive and so not cool. I've wanted to stop, but how?

Write about it, a friend suggested. My exasperated wife supported the idea of self-intervention.

So I sent an e-mail message to a former fellow shareholder, Simon Brady, explaining that I was planning to revisit my real estate decision of 1993. ''Wow, that would be painful,'' he shot back. And he would know, having lost even more on his apartment than I did on mine. But he agreed: ''It could be cathartic.''

I called the man who had lived with his wife and young children on the floor below us. Those Brooklyn days, he said, were a bad dream that he did not wish to publicly return to for personal reasons.

But for the record, he said he had paid $255,000 for his apartment and had sold it two months after we sold ours. He received $155,000, and paid $25,000 to the bank at closing, to make up a shortfall.

''We needed to find a place quickly after moving to New York and starting work, and that is how you lose $100,000 in a real estate deal,'' my old neighbor said. ''You're desperate to get in and desperate to get out. But I've never gone back to see what prices there were. I just put that part of my life behind me.''

Now, I am perfectly capable of chalking up a used car as a lemon. But I was going to have to dig deeper into myself to get over blowing what might have been a college education fund for two.

Next up for a years-overdue reunion were Mr. Brady and his wife, Rachel Look, who live in Rockville Centre, N.Y., with their two children. Perched on the floor above us, Rachel and Simon were known in our apartment as R and S because our toddler son, Alex, habitually presented them with the correct alphabet blocks when they stopped by after work to play on the carpet. Witnesses to budding genius, they were like extended family.

But Mr. Brady, an equity derivatives broker, was transferred to London in 1992, shortly after the birth of their daughter. His request to sublet precipitated a stomach-churning dispute that put me between the interests of my friends and the shareholders, who feared that allowing more apartments to become owner unoccupied would make it even more difficult to sell.

Mr. Brady was turned down. His apartment remained empty, depriving us of upstairs neighbors and him of about $2,500 a month.

''I do remember lying in bed in London at night, thinking that I'd just paid my rent here and my mortgage and maintenance in Brooklyn and I'm getting hammered,'' he said over dinner in the old neighborhood. ''Now I wonder: Why didn't I put up more of a fight?''

In early 1994, Mr. Brady got a call from his broker. There was an offer, finally. ''Here I had a two-bedroom in Brooklyn Heights, with parking, sold it for $155,000, lost almost $100,000 and thought, 'Thank God,' '' he said.

Ms. Look laughed. Mr. Brady looked at her quizzically.

''What else can you do?'' she said.

Mr. Brady said, ''Cry?''

Unlike her husband, and more like my wife, Ms. Look said she never lost sleep over the deal.

''The way I've always looked at it,'' she said, ''is that because the market was so bad, we could all move into houses that we couldn't have afforded if the market had been good.''

This was a fair point and an excellent rationalization. But as none of us had taken a dime out of our apartments, we hadn't had to sell them to move. In hindsight, allowing open-ended subletting until the market improved would have been the prudent strategy.

Next I went to see our old first-floor neighbors, Aaron Marcu and Mary Lu Bilek, who still live in Brooklyn Heights. There, Ms. Bilek posed the crucial question: ''Were any of us at the time really prepared to be shareholders and landlords for one day longer than necessary?''

Mr. Marcu and Ms. Bilek had the largest apartment of the four, a duplex with two bathrooms and 500 square feet in the basement. They had bought it in 1985, the year the buildings became a co-op. Mr. Marcu, a lawyer, and Ms. Bilek, an associate dean at the School of Law of the City University of New York, were the first to discover the headaches that came with our sister building next door.

''None of us could have known how much of an albatross the other building was going to be,'' Mr. Marcu said.

Having inherited several rent-controlled apartments there, the sponsors fell thousands of dollars behind on their maintenance payments. As treasurer, Ms. Bilek had to badger them monthly. Routine maintenance required hasty assessments. City tax bills went unpaid. Foreclosure was possible. This was the news my wife and I were greeted with at our first board meeting.

Eventually, with the help of a building manager, the sponsors were forced to transfer their shares to an investor who was willing to cover their debt. Presented with the keys to his new kingdom, our savior proceeded to sneak into the other building, which housed our utilities, to turn off the heat on frigid winter nights.

His goal was to freeze out the renters, but he conveniently forgot about the welfare of the shareholders and their young children. As president, I reluctantly assumed the role of middle-of-the-night super.

Mr. Marcu and Ms. Bilek, who now have twin college-age sons, sold their apartment in 1994 for what they had paid nine years earlier, around $200,000, but only after several deals had fallen through, including one for $380,000.

Mr. Marcu said he had no regrets. Testing his fortitude, I reported that his old apartment had recently been advertised on Trulia.com for $1.395 million. He winced slightly, but recovered quickly.

''We didn't make a good business decision,'' he said. ''But I'd like to think we made a good life decision. As long as we were there, the situation with the other building wasn't going to change.''

I wondered about that on my way to a meeting with John Grathwol, who bought the Brady-Look apartment 15 years ago and is the co-op's current president. Back at the building for the first time since 1993, I rang the buzzer. There was no sound. My God, I wondered, could this be the same intercom that always shorted out in winter because it had been inexpertly installed? I felt a little better already.

Mr. Grathwol, who works for the New York City Office of Budget and Management, invited Sven Grell, a banker and the owner of my old apartment, to join us. I regaled them with stories about the co-op's tumultuous history.

Mr. Grathwol brought me up to date, explaining that six of the 10 units next door were now owned by the estate of the second investor. Only two apartments remain rent-controlled. The two-building partnership was still a time-consuming challenge, he said, but the co-op had stabilized financially during the real estate boom.

I asked what they believed their apartments were worth and braced myself. If recent appraisals for refinancing were accurate, almost $900,000, Mr. Grathwol said. He smiled like a man whose purchase price -- on paper, anyway -- had more than quadrupled.

Alright, I admit it, it was a blow, but not as much of one as it might have been before I began my therapy.

''Two bedrooms in this neighborhood with parking, it's always going to be gold,'' he said.

Why hadn't that been obvious to us?

Climbing to Mr. Grathwol's apartment, I had had a flashback. How had I forgotten that early in my wife's second pregnancy with our son Charly, she had been bedridden? That I had fretted constantly about her walking up the stairs? Clearly, we all had our distractions back then, and we were exhausted after years of living through the co-op wars. But with emerging careers, we at least had options, the ability to go elsewhere and start over as home buyers.

And after reconnecting with our old neighbors, the other thought I am left with -- and hope to hang onto -- is that as much money as we lost, judging a period of life by the bottom line is the road to existential ruin. We took away good memories from Brooklyn, too.

When Mr. Grell graciously offered us the chance to revisit our old apartment, Beth and I couldn't help but share nostalgic glances. Even if Alex had no recollection of ever having been there, this was where we had started our family.

I suppose, then, that the closure I have been looking for might be in the realization that the apartment was never just an investment. It was a place to live.

PHOTOS: (PHOTOGRAPH BY TONY CENICOLA/THE NEW YORK TIMES); HEARTBREAK HOUSE: A building in Brooklyn was home to four families who were compelled to sell for various reasons in the poor real estate market of the early '90s. The author, whose young family was among them, recently caught up with some of the others in an attempt to come to terms with a chronic case of seller's remorse. (PHOTOGRAPH BY MICHAEL APPLETON FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES) (RE1); TIME WAS: In the real estate doldrums of 1993, Harvey Araton sold his apartment in a problem-plagued Brooklyn Heights co-op for a song. He later came down with a bad case of real estate regret. As a cure, he revisited the place, above. Below, Mr. Araton in the apartment when his son Alex was a toddler, and with Alex there the other day. (PHOTOGRAPH COURTESY OF HARVEY ARATON); SOMETHING IN COMMON: John Grathwol and Rosann Berry, left, in their apartment in the building, purchased 15 years ago. Aaron Marcu and Mary Lu Bilek, who were Mr. Araton's neighbors, are philosophical about the low price they got for their place in 1994. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY MICHAEL APPLETON FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES) (RE8)

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100117e61h0001f


IN THE REGION CONNECTICUT
Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
At Year's End, Sales Picked Up Pace
By LISA PREVOST
1050 words
17 January 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
5
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

CORRECTION APPENDED

Because of an editing error, the ''In the Region'' article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday, about the state of the housing market in Connecticut, referred incorrectly to 14 sales in New Canaan in 2008. That was the number for the fourth quarter, not ''all of 2008.''

CORRECTED BY THE NEW YORK TIMES Sun Jan 24 2010

COMING off one of the worst years ever for the housing market, Connecticut has reason to be hopeful that 2010 will be better -- chiefly because it is hard to imagine the economy sliding precipitously enough for sales to fall still further.

As of the end of November (the latest month for which data was available), 22,200 single-family homes had sold statewide in 2009, a decline of 4 percent from the same period in 2008. By comparison, in 2006, the number of transactions exceeded 32,000. The median price slid by 11 percent statewide -- more like 15 to 20 percent in hard-hit Fairfield County.

Builders all but stopped building in 2009. The number of permits issued had not broken 3,000 as of the end of November, a ''pretty terrible'' tally compared with the more ''normal'' level of 11,000 to 12,000 permits a year, said Peter M. Gioia, the economist for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association.

Still, there are signs that the correction is nearly complete. The market picked up markedly toward the end of the year, with sales volume up an impressive 75 percent in November, according to the Warren Group, a real estate data provider in Boston.

Mr. Gioia said he was confident that the state's housing market was, in fact, in recovery, with Fairfield County being a possible exception. He cautioned, however, that upward progress would be slow.

''We're in a modest uptick,'' he explained, ''but we're at the very beginning of it.''

Connecticut doesn't have an overbuilt market to contend with, like Florida or Nevada, for example. However, market stability has been undermined by job loss, extended unemployment and persistent foreclosure activity. And far from adding jobs this year, Connecticut employers are likely to lay off another 15,000 workers, Mr. Gioia said.

Unemployment, estimated by the state at 8 to 9 percent, is abetting the rise in foreclosure filings. In the state's court-based foreclosure mediation program, which was made mandatory last year for all eligible foreclosure actions, the number of cases in mediation in the last quarter of 2009 rose 19 percent over the previous year, to 6,742.

Of the 4,448 cases mediated between mid-2008, when the program began, and Oct. 31, 2009, 61 percent have resulted in a modification of loan terms that allows owners to stay in their homes, said Roberta Palmer, the program manager.

The long-term success of those modifications, however, is unknown. The court has not figured out a way to track what percentage wind up back in default, Ms. Palmer said.

Until now the state's poorest cities have borne the brunt of the foreclosure crisis. But filings of notices of pending foreclosure lawsuits -- called lis pendens -- are showing up more frequently in town clerks' offices in affluent suburbs.

Although the total numbers are still small relative to cities like Bridgeport and New Haven, lis pendens, the first step in Connecticut's foreclosure process, were up 75 to 115 percent last year in the Fairfield County towns of Greenwich, New Canaan, Westport and Wilton, according to the Warren Group.

Along with the federal first-time home-buyer tax credit and low interest rates, growing seller anxiety could be contributing to increased sales activity. Tim Sickinger, a partner in Ladd Financial, a mortgage company in Westport, said that although purchases had definitely picked up over the last few months, he had also noticed that ''the sellers tend to be more distressed,'' especially in the higher price ranges.

In Greenwich last year, sales were so slow that the 10 sales in the first 8 days of this month encouraged Russell Pruner, an owner of Shore &Country Properties.

Mr. Pruner said he thought that 2009 would ''end up the worst year in the history of Greenwich real estate.''

Home values in town have dropped 25 to 33 percent over the past two years, and houses priced accordingly are drawing buyer interest, Mr. Pruner said. Like Mr. Gioia, Mr. Pruner isn't ready to declare that the Greenwich-area market has hit bottom.

But he thinks the market may have fallen far enough to entice the renters waiting in the wings.

''We truly have pent-up demand,'' he said. ''We've got 100-plus people in rentals paying $10,000, $15,000 a month. That was a smart move in 2009, but will they pony up again for 2010? I don't think they will.''

Sales in New Canaan also picked up at the end of the year, with 35 fourth-quarter sales, as opposed to 14 in all of 2008, according to Denise Gannalo, an agent with William Raveis. Among those sales was a bank-owned property she originally listed for $3.9 million. The six-bedroom property finally sold for $1.9 million.

While encouraged by rising sales, Ms. Gannalo sees trouble ahead for some who bought in 2005, the height of the market. This year alone, the average selling price in New Canaan fell by 21 percent, which may mean that some highly leveraged homeowners now owe more than their house is worth, she said.

Even as home values have declined, land prices have remained high in Fairfield County, as well as in other parts of the state. That is making it doubly difficult for builders to re-enter the market, said George LaCava, the president of Trilacon Development Corporation in Cromwell, and the president of the Homebuilders Association of Connecticut.

Land seems to be one investment that people are holding onto as a hedge, betting that it will hold its value, he said.

PHOTO: COMPLETE WITH RUSTIC WALL: A house for sale on Sherwood Avenue in Greenwich, where agents say well-priced properties are drawing interest. (PHOTOGRAPH BY DOUGLAS HEALEY FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100117e61h0001c


Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
Making History In a Brooklyn Neighborhood
By JEFF VANDAM
1173 words
17 January 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
2
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

WHEN Habitat for Humanity New York City consulted an architecture firm on its new site in the Ocean Hill section of Brownsville, Brooklyn, it received a response that switched on a light bulb. The firm, Dattner Architects, said that Habitat could proceed with its plan to build 12 town houses on the trash-strewn vacant lot, but that the site was actually capable of supporting many more units in apartment form -- 41, to be exact.

The result, nearly three years and one entirely new development model later, is the largest creation in Habitat's history, an $11.6 million three-building complex on Atlantic Avenue, complete with LEED Gold certification. About 10,000 requests were received for the 41 slots; the applicants eventually selected were required to make down payments of 1 percent on the building's condominiums, which ranged in price from $75,000 to $200,000. They were also required to invest 300 hours of work, which Habitat, a nonprofit organization, calls ''sweat equity,'' in the development.

''In the past, they were building single-family dwellings, not a 41-unit complex as they did here on Atlantic Avenue,'' said Rosalyn Jolly, a hospital clerical associate who recently moved from a cramped one-bedroom in Bushwick into a two-bedroom in the complex with her 15-year-old daughter. ''It's a wonderful thing.''

Now, perhaps with the notion that it is onto something, Habitat has begun altering its model in New York City. The volunteers so often photographed putting up the walls of a standalone house, sometimes with a smiling Jimmy Carter in tow, are now helping erect larger buildings (alongside future residents). And the city's branch of Habitat just learned last week that it will receive about $10.5 million in funding from the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, part of a $2 billion outlay to help nonprofits and governments expand their services for affordable housing.

In the South Bronx, a 50-unit co-op building on Fox Street is mostly finished, and in February, Habitat will begin taking applications for a development a few blocks away. The 63-unit building on Prospect Avenue at Macy Place, for which final city approval was recently granted, is rising above the neighborhood, visible from the elevated train platform of the 2 and 5 subway lines down the street. Volunteers are to start work there in March.

''New York is a very dense city,'' said Ingrid Gould Ellen, a professor of public policy and urban planning at New York University's Wagner Graduate School of Public Service. ''So I think that building to the density levels that fit into the neighborhood landscape makes a lot of sense.'' The affordable-homeownership market, she said wryly, ''is not a market that is glutted right now.''

Yet Habitat is taking on this new role of low-income condominium developer at a difficult time for such housing in New York. In fiscal year 2009, a 16-unit Habitat development in Bedford-Stuyvesant was the only below-market-rate homeownership deal to close with the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. (In 2008, the total number was 24; in 2007, 27.) While Habitat works in ownership situations, the rental market is also struggling; the number of affordable units available per 100 extremely low-income households in New York State fell to 36 from 38 in 2008, according to the National Low Income Housing Coalition.

This situation exists despite Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's $7.5 billion affordable-housing initiative, created in 2003, which seeks to ''create or preserve'' 165,000 units. With 97,000 units financed thus far, according to the housing agency, the plan is on track to meet its goals by 2014, but demand remains high; the city's vacancy rate is 2.9 percent.

In this environment, Habitat has tripled its number of units under construction in the past six months -- thanks in part, it says, to its sweat-equity ownership model.

''Ideally, in our quest to serve as many families in need as possible, what we want to do is to be as nimble and as entrepreneurial as possible,'' said Josh Lockwood, Habitat's executive director in New York City.

Applicants, 90 percent of whom are typically rejected quickly, must submit to a home visit and interviews as well as maintain a 620 credit score. Under a loan agreement between Habitat and the State of New York Mortgage Agency, buyers putting in 300 hours of work on their buildings receive a 2 percent interest rate, which Habitat buys down to zero percent. In addition to the 1 percent they put down, buyers make monthly payments equal to a third of their incomes.

''We don't give anything away,'' Mr. Lockwood said. ''These families have to build their own homes.''

The cost of building for Habitat is reduced further by fund-raising and the large pool of volunteers. Of course, given market conditions and land availability in the city, not every new endeavor can be as ambitious as the Ocean Hill complex.

In the Bronx, Habitat's two new buildings are partnerships with the Blue Sea Development Company, which has worked with the city on affordable housing in the past. That means about three-quarters of the units will not be sold under the Habitat sweat-equity terms described above -- although they will still be sold below market rate, and are therefore considered affordable housing. Indeed, the word ''Habitat'' isn't in evidence on the banners on those buildings (the words ''Affordable Housing'' are); Habitat says it is marketing its share of the units through its normal means.

''The hope is that we can use both models,'' Mr. Lockwood said.

Either way, new residents are happy. Taking a group of visitors through her family's earth-toned two-bedroom at Atlantic Avenue, Mirian Rodriguez spoke with pride, and some surprise, about the construction skills she had learned over the last year.

''I knew what Sheetrock was, but I didn't know how to put it in,'' she said. ''You had to be on your knees.'' She works part time at Jamaica Hospital; her husband, Miguel Baez, works as a porter in Manhattan.

Their place is filled with new appliances, a gift from her parents (''It was on sale,'' she says), along with a big-boy bed for her son, Adrian, and all the Hot Wheels paraphernalia that can fit in one child's room. It's a far cry from the tiny one-bedroom they rented in Cypress Hills, Brooklyn, with crime and commotion in the hallways. The new place is quiet and comfortable, and it smells good.

''We're very thankful,'' she said. ''It's ours.''

PHOTOS: NEW MODEL: Habitat for Humanity New York City recently built a green three-building complex on Atlantic Avenue, the largest in its history. Mirian Rodriguez moved into a two-bedroom there. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY ANDREA MOHIN/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

The New York Times Company
